review_title: BP is a large fraternity house
pros: Interesting industry and a company with plenty of brain power
cons: For those who come to BP right out of school, there is better opportunity and mentorship provided, but for those who come to BP as experienced hires, it is very difficult to develop a professional career. It is difficult to move up, it is difficult to receive training and mentorship, it is difficult to receive recognition for good work and years of relevant experience. It is also difficult to break into the fraternity. The social structure is very much like that of a fraternity house.

review_title: It is good experience at first steps in oil industry.
pros:
1 good places to work at, (comapre with other local companies - Azerbaijan). 
2 base salary is better than average base pay in country.
3 provides good social package 
4 uses late technologies on field
5 a lot overseas experties, so you can get different views on problem.
cons:
1.Career progress, is not as fast as you would like to have
2. Have to go through pleanty of mandatory trainings/courses/roles/activities, which some times is not what you need, even when you give a strong reasons for that.
3 base pay amount has significant gap with average salary in oil industry worldwide
4 people listen to you, but not acting
5 Can not get international assigment even for short period of time

review_title: Good company but lots of improvements needed.
pros: Good work life balance,  good pay and benefits package. Relaxed management,  good value and behaviour in place. Global exposure.
cons: No progression.  Old line managers have become comfortable in thier positions with a very little knowledge of the outside world.  They have become the biggest barriers in the Junior, s future growth hence they leave with dissatisfaction and overall company suffers. No amount of package or benefits are enough if future growth is not there.

pros: Fair salary, good benefits, good annual cash bonus. Extremely flexible company when it comes to allowing home working. Great employee assistance programme.
cons: Overcomplicated processes and systems, not keeping up with the speed, technology and service required in the 21th century to be competitive in the market. Still lots of "old dogs" at the company who are stuck with the old ways of working and not able to change and improve. Lots of politics and false promises about trying to make things better.

review_title: Run as fast as you can
pros: You can work from home which is a nice benefit and the other benefits are nice as well
cons: One of the worst poorly run and managed companies I have ever worked for. The management does not care about their people. They hire friends that are highly under qualified. Which in turn results in horrible working conditions for everyone else. It is one of the most toxic, demoralizing environments I have ever seen. They downsize and get rid of people they don't like or that have the gall to voice opinions and then re-organize and rehire new people. Their value statements are all lies.

pros:
Flat structure means those in more junior roles get good access to senior staff.

Good values (however these aren’t always enforced).
cons:
Inflexible policy on working from home. Very much depends on the relevant department. Please check before you join and get flexible working as part of employment contract if this is something you need, as BP are inflexible once you’re ‘in the door’.

As some employees leave the company, replacements are not always found. This means more work is piled on the staff that remain.

review_title: Peter Sutherland may be "leading" BP but as an employee you wouldn't know it - the Board is invisible
pros: Innovation, vision, importance of energy, political importance. The oil and gas industry is at the centre of most things going on in the world. It  is endlessly interesting. There is a great can-do mentality in the business.
cons: size, way company is structured, clientism/patronage, lack of recognition. Since the downsizing of the 1990s the company has been run as a kind of confederation in which busines units have wide autonomy and, from the employee perspective, it is near-impossible to plan a career - so everyone has a short term mentality and they key to success and longevity is to hitch your wagon to a rising star/growing asset

review_title: A once great company struggling to find its identity in the post Macondo world
job_title: Business Planning Manager in Houston, TX
pros:
Great people, collaborative work environment.

Company really cares about people.  Good work/life balance policies supported by leadership
cons:
The company is very complex.  Sometimes, it's not always clear who is accountable for what, so performance is not always addressed in the way that it should.   In my 15 years there I don't think I have ever had really clear feedback on my performance.

I do not think the management has the ability to address BP's cultural and organization issues.

pros:
Lots of flexibility
Great benefits
Mostly good and smart people as a result of rigorous selection processes
Plenty of development opportunities if you seek them out and take advantage of availability; getting ahead is very much a matter of networking and making things happen for yourself
cons:
Seemed like there was constant restructuring at department, function, and/or corporate level, so overall strategy was questionable.
Personality assessments given as part of selection were rigged at times. (I know because the YSC psychologist admitted to me that she slanted one assessment to get me away from a specific manager and was willing to revise the same assessment to give me a better shot at another opportunity!)

review_title: Moved to Houston just before a major company reorg
pros:
Awesome coworkers who were always willing to help
Felt like company recognized and respected that employees had life outside of work
Managers took time to check in with employees
Lots of internal classes and opportunities to grow
Great campus, 2 gyms, 3 cafeterias, easy access to running/biking trails
Great packages offered during layoffs
cons:
Very unstable at the moment with numerous waves of layoffs due to reorganization
Tons of hoops to jump through when you have a problem
No insight as to where the company is headed or why layoffs are happening like they are
Moving to a more open floorplan, which none of the employees support

job_title: Project Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent company culture. The company really cares about it's employees and takes care of them. Great benefits and a very supportive environment with lots of potential to advance. They really do care about the work life balance of their employees and provide flexible work schedules as well as supporting working remotely. Excellent pay and reliable benefits as they don't track sick days but just let the employee take time off for illness when they need to.
cons: Not the most financially stable company right now due to low oil prices and oil spill fines. Also, the safety culture is totally over the top and sometimes makes day to day work difficult, but they do take the safety of their employees very seriously.

review_title: BP Australia- best years are behind them
pros:
Good remuneration
Opportunities for development early in career
Some really smart people
Lots of challenges
cons:
BP Australia has had 3 major restructuring in past 2.5 years - created poor environment for trust or respect, every one watching their backs, materially diminished development opportunities. 
The poor leadership and very slow decision making
Lacks clear vision for the future 
Highly political- a lot of back stabbing and posturing especially in the Executive leadership team, decisions get made on what's best for individuals rather than the business 
Ignores or fails to address workplace impact on both physical or mental health of individuals due to high workload and reduced staff numbers

pros:
Good insurance (medical, dental, life, pet, etc.)
Decent pay - depending on business segment pay may be more competitive
Company match of charity donations
401K match
cons:
BP underwent a lot of change over the past three years across the company. There has been job loss and people doing more with less. 
Removal of work flexibility, coupled with reorganization / transformations  hurt morale. 
Culture varies depending on where you work - some good, some not so good - inconsistent across company.

review_title: Good place for an entry level candidate
pros: There is good opportunities for growth and the entry level compensation is above average. BP is one of the major oils so it is what it is. There are opportunities to advance if you are willing to put in the work. I got my job through on campus interviews.
cons: Some of the downsides are the amount of feedback you recieve for your work. In my opinion it is not where it should be yet. In addition I think the company could do more in terms of diversity and mentoring programs. Overall I've been happy with the way things have been going and see myself being here for awhile.

pros: Good salaries and benefits.  Prestige of working for a supermajor in Oil & Gas industry.  Continual job opportunities all over the world.
cons: Nobody is empowered to make a decision.  A lot of talk, but little or no action.  Each project either remains uncompleted or takes a left turn.  Excellent strategy, but little execution.

review_title: Enjoyable Work, Great Culture, Great Work/Life Balance
pros:
-Tons of work opportunities, especially early in your career.  Can take some time as a young engineer to find where you fit best and land there. 
-Culture is great, and the people are as well. 
-9/80 schedule is great (every other Friday off, working 9 hours per day every other day).  Essentially its ~20 days of vacation each year in addition to the vacation package you already have.
cons:
-Typical big company cons: slow turnaround for decisions, bureaucracy, etc. 
-Sometimes the company tends to ride the oil industry roller-coaster more than most.  When things are good, they're great, but when something happens (ex. Gulf Spill), things may get prohibitively expensive, hard to do, etc.

review_title: Get out while you still can
pros: In the oil and gas industry you receive better pay than many opportunities which is also the case at BP.  There are still a number of quality people to work with at BP.
cons: Management is by and large incompetent (starting at the very top and trickling down to those who have to interact with the lowly plebes who actually do work) and reached their lofty positions by delivering good sales pitches as opposed to producing quality results, showing sound leadership, and having any form of business acumen.  This is taken out on individual contributors who suffer the consequences of the downturn.  Individual contributors who achieve and those who are recognized for achievement are not significantly overlapping in a Venn Diagram.

pros: Good benefits, gym at the campus, knowledgeable employees, work-life balance. They treat their employees with dignity and respect especially during restructuring.
cons: Some employees can back-stabbed you especially when they feel that you know more than then and their lack of knowledge might be exposed. Some employees take credit for your work behind you. Their ranking system might need some improvement as it is not very fair as it sometimes has to do with your boss liking you even though you are not an exceptional employee, you might end up getting a very high ranking.

review_title: Doesn't value its real assets - people
pros:
- The best group of people I have ever worked with in terms of intellect, capability and ambition
- Really good work-life balance; in effect you work your own hours and can flex as required, can work from home 1 day a week as long as you deliver how you do it is of minimal importance
- Autonomy in role
- Transparency of Senior Management in comms re: Deepwater Horizon
cons:
- BP's performance management leaves a lot to be desired.  No feedback culture whatsoever.
- Set on hiring at Senior levels so very little if any succession planning means that top talent gets frustrated and leaves
- Fairly low morale post Gulf of Mexico incident; BP doesnt seem to be acknowledging this either

review_title: Career Suicide/Low Morale - Do not work in HR!
job_title: Human Resources Staff in Sunbury, England
pros:
Competitive Salary
Prestigious company
Each department has its own set of cultures ( you may work in Shipping and love it!)
cons:
Unethical management 
Second class culture towards contracted staff
Poor leadership
Work Life imbalance (can work 12 hours a day)
Lack of development opportunities
Extremely high turnover within HR

review_title: BP lacks good management and HR
pros:
Good pay and good benefits 
Sponsors the Rodeo
Good bonus
cons: Management uses HR to do their dirty work. Management uses "the process" and manipulates it to get what they want!  They will always say "it's not what you accomplished but how" so if you save $20m bucks and the stakeholder has a hissy for over something then all that's focused on is the hissy fit. HR does everything  managers want. From hiring externals to pushing good folks out. The employee has no power so forget it if you pissed off a manager your doomed. Don't believe anything they tell you like "we encourage work life balance" then when you use it they make an issue of it. Could not take it anymore so had to quit!

pros: Not sure about other countries, but in Azerbaijan  its  a good job just to survive and  this company dont have any future at least in Azerbaijan,  all qualified people with  good mind are leaving this company,
cons: I used to work  there for 18 years. Beginning was great. I had some developments,  challenges. Expats were good and they had a tendency to develop locals. but the last 10 years - no improvements. No diversity, no inclusion, no equal opportunity.

pros: Flexible working environment with encouragement to take a day to 2 days to work from home (depends on team lead). There are opportunity for lateral movement among departments. The people here are generally nice and helpful. There are fun activities and events such as Employee Value Proposition, movie day, family day, CSR, etc.
cons: Benefits are lower than other Oil & Gas shared services companies. Management doesn't seem to care much about the employees' as long as they can fulfill their projects and performance target. Although they emphasize on team work, but the management themselves are very self-driven

review_title: Good company aside from Learnings Ops
pros: Good work culture, work/life balance and career prospects generally in BP. People across the company are committed, work well together and management are supportive of employees, as well as company objectives. Deserving of it's 'best place to work' in almost all business areas.
cons: The review ratings are based on Learning Ops. Learning Ops falls short of the above statements. The environment is intimidating, management  un-supportive of and not listening to team opinions or suggestions. Flexibility is low, virtually non existent - goes against the rest of the BP culture.

pros: After all this time, I can’t think of any.
cons: Management doesn’t have a clear vision. L48 headquarters was moved to Denver, even though most of the onshore assets are in Texas. There is a Denver vs. Houston mentality which originated from the current onshore CEO. L48 has been laying off high performers in Houston and the field, which has caused safety issues, but are hiring positions that are laughable at best like Culture Representatives and Executive Concierge in Denver. The Denver office is spending money as if L48 is an oil driven company, but it’s not. L48 is a gas driven company.

review_title: Great company that accomondates your personal needs, but limited professional growth due to constant reorganizations
pros: A good company that's willing to accomondate your personal needs. Enjoyed great work-life balance here and management has been really understanding to one's personal needs.  As this is a global company, you can find opportunities within the company at a location that you might need to be. The company also greatly supports rotating through different roles and locations.
cons: Uncertainties around the organization makes BP an inefficient place to work and to grow professionally. BP has been undergoing too many reorgs, making it difficult for contuinity of work. Clarity around one's responsibilities and accountabilites is also limited, thus decisions are made but rarely followed through.

pros: I really enjoy working at BP because they treat their people well. The work is enjoyable, the atmosphere is pleasant, and interaction with each other is encouraged. Personal wellness is stressed and I feel like at the end of the day, the company does care and will take care of you.
cons: Like all big business, the bureaucratic aspects of the job can become overwhelming at times. It occasionally feels like there is so much process involved that it becomes difficult to sort through it all and actually do our jobs.

review_title: Having to reapply for your job each year because management want to change something
pros: The shares and bonus you get. Also the compressed working week they do but stopping in Jan as they are making cut backs but can still afford to sponser London 2012 which is going to cost them about £40M. The xmas parties were always good but sure we probably wont be getting one of these either this year.
cons: Having to reapply for your job each year because management want to change something and then you end up with the same job anyway. Total waste of time. The air con in the office doesn't work. the food in the canteen is gross. My manager has no people skills at all.

review_title: This is a warmer and fuzzier energy company and efficiency and common sense are non-existent.
pros: They are very understanding when employees need to take time to address personal issues.
cons: The management seems to be working in a fantasy world no one else can find.  They set unobtainable goals and if a goal is close to being reached, they change it to one that can't be reached.  Morale is not doing well.  This company is full of compulsive starters, but it's hard to find someone that will do the follow-up work.

review_title: Organization still struggling and very much in flux after 2010 Gulf of Mexico disaster.
pros: Good work life balance.  Excellent compensation and benefits. Strong functional/technical communities of practice.  Wide range of opportunities associated with large organization.  Excellent acceptance of diverse cultures.
cons: Poor Leadership, poor ability to define, plan and achieve strong business delivery.  Organization has herd mentality,  fails to identify key issues and gets lost in details.  A small power group controls messages and fails to take advantage of the strength of  the organization.   Over reliance on official processes over common sense.  Over reliance on a global assurance model over local expertise.

review_title: Sadly Far away from what it used to be
pros: Still one of the big companies with large reserves, still an integrated major Oil, gas, production and distribution (upstream and downstream)
cons:
No real progression by merits, everything depends on who you know and you could climb 2, 3 or even more grades in the blink of an eye. If you are connected the could move you sideways in management or VP positions no matter if you have a clue.
Extremely disproportioned agenda to place women, LGBT members on management, it almos looks like discrimination against the so called majority.

review_title: Great company, lacks individual development plan
pros: Environmentally friendly, work life balance is important to both employees and management.  Active Corporate Social Responsible Plan, both globally and locally.  Energy is at the forefront of the world's agenda and bp is a major player in creation and development of current and new energy sources.
cons: Not enough HR power.  The group is under funded and staffed and thus lacks the ability to create sustainable employee development programs.  This reduces employee happiness and ultimately forces good people to leave for other organizations.

review_title: Good company overall, too many "Yes Men"
pros: They pay good, decent benefits (school reimbursement, 401k match, pension, medical, etc). Many opportunities (they are the 4th largest company in the world, assets all over, all types of jobs). Solid job market (constantly hiring most positions, many contract opportunities).
cons: "Yes Men" seem to get management positions about 3/4 of the time, with or without proper qualifications; so all the issues that come with that... Too many processes and procedures that become the focus vs. the actual work. Too much of a "we're all equal" attitude, so the guy doing nothing gets the same recognition as the guy doing all the work (or more sometimes..). They seem to get stuck on pedigree vs. qualifications, so many unqualified people in upper positions.

review_title: slow, pondering, proud of how smart people are
pros: travel the globe in business class at the drop of a hat. Great bonus plan, really interesting work at times, mostly fun people to work alongside.
cons: Management does not listen, they pretend to listen and then do not change. I worked with the to level people and watched many of them leave..then what is left behind is 2d class. pride and arrogance ..the british way. HR runs the company and does not have a clue. Most decisions made in a meeting with a blind eye to what is happening in the field.

review_title: A shadow of its former self
pros: Decent pay, decent benefits, depending on the manager, decent work atmosphere, great work out facilities, good location,  Well that is about all the pros I can think of.
cons: BP was a great place to work in the beginning.  But due to mismanagement and poor leadership, the company has backed itself into a corner.  The company is so full of red tape that its unbelievable that anything can ever get done.  It is a good place to work if you like sitting around doing nothing and going to useless meetings.  No one will make a decision, things just go on and on and on with no end or resolution.

pros: I liked working here because I like seeing new people everyday and I like the hectic nature of the job working the cash register in a gas station. I like that my job entailed many different things other than just working the cash register.
cons: I was not paid well at all I was working 3rd Shift and a very bad neighborhood and working up to 65 hours a week and not even receiving overtime pay. More often than not the people that were supposed to come in to let me go home wouldn't show on time and I would get stuck staying up to 3 hours after my shift was supposed to end.

review_title: Treated well as employee, great team experience.
job_title: IT Support Analyst in London, England
pros: Good employee benefits, work-life flexibility, and very comfortable work environment. Personally I really enjoyed my team and the team work / challenges involved.
cons:
Training budgets are allocated, but seldom used. Practically speaking existing work responsibilities take preference. Employee career progression and training was neglected in my experience. Human Resources were of little help in this regard.
Progressive ideas are not infrequently filtered out by bureaucratic red-tape, policies and procedures. These issues can also stifle work efficiency.

pros: Awesome working schedule. Great people and a nice package with the Alaska premium. Moved all the way from Houston Texas.
cons: Big company so you must have a back up plan when oil goes low you must have invested your money. Alaska sold 1/3 of there assets all of Milne point to hilcorp. There was supposively 40% layoffs in BP Alaska. Also the future is not looking good either if you google BP Alaska it looks as if the company is willing to sell there whole Alaska headquarters. This is not a good time to be in the oilfield

review_title: Company in crisis (and don't the employees know it!)
pros: Nice office, shame about the management that inhabit it! I'd have given it zero starts but can't! The only good thing is the plush office. Even the CMMS system is a BP lashup job as a stop gap before they move on to a proper one!
cons:
Money is poor compare to peers, management lurch from one great idea to the next (driven by those above changing their "strategic priorities" on a whim!). 
Management that have more faces than a town hall clock and have absolutely no idea how to lead! 
All in all, it's a big name with a poor attitude!

pros: Good company to work for in general when the O&G prices were up.  They're doing most of the right things to keep the company going forward for the future under the current market conditions.
cons: HR has done a very poor job during the massive layoffs.

review_title: Good marketing material, the story is different once you're inside
pros: Global energy major, with presence in over 60 countries. Robust governance structure and commitments with external stakeholders. Awareness of the importance to attract new generations into the energy sector.
cons: Dated and inflexible top management not prepared to visualize and lead through  challenges faced by energy industry, to adapt to demand for sustainable, innovative global energy solutions.

pros: BP is a well-known company and it is a good name on CV.  If you want to work in the oil industry, it might not be a bad place to start.  However, unless you are a native-born English, chances for promotion are minimal.  Hence, careerwise, it is not an employer of choice.
cons: the turnover was high and it was a perfect reflection of the job satisfaction that employees had there - just a little over 0.  Pay was low, promotion was impossible, the environment was very political.  there was very little empowerment on the side of management.  the only advantage would be the central location of the office in Moscow.

pros: BP hires some of the best minds in their particular field and it shows. There are great benefits that come from working with any supermajor such as a nice gym, discounts, and 401k plans. BP has 9/80 weeks so you get every other friday off which really helps with work/life balance. Many of the employees are over 45, so there will be lots of opportunities for younger employees.
cons: Typical cons of working for any large corporation: performance driven culture, change takes forever yet constantly occurs, hard to not work while on long vacations, etc. Engineers and geologists are put on a pedestal, so sometimes other functions feel like they are less important.

pros: BP is an excellent place to work.  Corporate values include safety, diversity, excellence, courage, and "one team", and every employee or contractor I have worked with adheres to these values and speaks up whenever they notice behaviors that don't reflect corporate values.  I have never had a more satisfying work experience.  During layoff periods, employees and contractors are given plenty of advance notice and encouraged to actively seek other employment.
cons: Contractors often are not invited to town hall meetings, especially during the recent layoff periods. As a contractor, I had to rely on others to share what was discussed in town halls.

review_title: Interview and I Knew to Run
pros: It appeared to be a very thought out interview where they had a panel interview of people following the star process. They also tested you and asked situational questions. It appeared as if they had good cultural values, benefits,  and solid management staff.
cons: I interviewed and you could tell no one laughed, spoke to one another, very tense. Even the people interviewing looked tired. I was told there was a pension but when I asked about it, no! Now the recruiter told me there was. So, is this a trick to hire people? Ask everyone the same questions to make sure you have the same answers! The benefits for health care are the same at other places. I think they have lost their value in IL.

review_title: BP A Changing Company for the good or the bad
pros: Flexiblity of job changes and learning of other jobs in the company. Also posting of oppportunities in the company and you can change from one area to another. Fairness of pressure to get work done.
cons: Never know how things are going to change next day. A lot of changes for nothing and just for change. Sometimes I think things are changed just to be changed and look as if managers are doing something and managing.

review_title: Fantastic opportunities for personal development and offers an enviable work-life balance
pros:
- Abundance of opportunities for personal development 
- Good career roadmaps
- Plenty of international travel (at least as an engineer)
- Yet to hear of a company that offers a better work/life balance in terms of days off (flex fridays/away days/working from home possible)
- Great benefits package (medical, free lunch, generous personal allowance)
- Above-average salary, certainly for engineers
- Graduates have a very generous training budget
- Strong team ethos and quite a few team-building days/team-focussed events organised each year, alongside work parties.
- Great graduate network always organising get-togethers
cons:
- Outer london location (for me anyway)
- Still dealing with Macondo
- Average age of middle/senior management is high
- Very male-dominated in engineering... almost feels like an 'old boy's club' if you want to progress up the ladder

review_title: Good company to work for - pay, benefits, opportunities
pros:
Good pay and benefits
Work life balance is pretty decent depending on business unit/role
Competitive work environment  
Industry leader despite pr
cons:
- the above Pro's relies heavily on what business unit you're in.  IST/FVC/USPL are all embedded businesses where pay, 401k, tuition reimbursement GREATLY exceeds those at the "GBS".    
- every 2-3 years expect a re-org in your department w/ severance packages/layoffs
- career progress can be really hit or miss ~ pretty easy to advance within department/function, branching out to different businesses or functions is a different story.

review_title: Great company but is management up to keeping it like this?
pros: Professional and friendly colleagues; good benefits; good ethics. Interesting work.
cons:
Overly complicated structure and things keep changing all the time. The Functional model embedded in E&P since  Macondo has led to BP having more people post Macondo than pre Macondo and that is after asset divestitures. BP is therefore having to cut double hard with low oil prices. But meeting financial targets is not getting the share price up. Plus people find it hard to concentrate on safety and their jobs with all these cuts, uncertainty and change.

If you aren't a Brit will now be hard to get a senior position due to limitations on expats.

pros: Medical benefits are excellent  with free fitness facilities and trainers on campus.  Generally flexible working environment enabling reasonable balance between personal and professional lives, particularly for women with children.
cons: HR has created a hostile work environment by acting as BP's 'progressive police'.  A once wonderful work environment now boasts the likes of speech/behavior codes, mandatory 'diversity' training (think Google), and policies requiring employees to call out any and all 'perceived' offenses by colleagues and managers.   Numerous employees are routinely 'written up' by HR under the broad offense of 'disrespectful behavior'.  I was once proud  to work for BP and remain saddened by it deterioration into a 'witch hunt' environment.

review_title: If you want to be in oil & gas, be a BP employee and an Exxon shareholder
pros: The corporate culture tends to be entrepreneurial, flexible and creative.  Its up to the individual to create opportunities and benefit from them - you need to be driven to progress. Also the company is very diverse and tends to be a flat organisation.
cons: The downside of this culture is the lack of structure and constant change, that can be annoying when trying to think about your future career.  It feels like your career is not in your control but in whatever management wants do do with you and your career.

pros: Global opportunities available,excellent benefits. Opportunity to work with some really bright and capable people in pockets throughout the organization.  After several tough years, beginning in 2005 with the Texas City Refinery accident, senior leadership took the necessary steps to streamline the bureaucracy and address behaviors that led to incorrect priorities and poor decision making.  Bright future ahead for the company as the green economy expands.
cons: Operating units are rarely in desirable living locations, outside of Houston and limited staff in satellite offices (Chicago, L.A., etc.). Salary and clear career path options could be better to retain highly skilled employees outside of the engineering/technical functions.

pros: Pay is decent.  Benefits are ok outside of Alaska.
cons:
New position 9-16 months
Treat engineers as disposal resources
Management claims to care about employees and wanting feedback, but actually treat employees like servants and fire employees that give feedback that doesn't align with managements views.
The only way to get somewhere in BP is the be the child of an employee.  Nepotism is the name of the game at BP.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Farnham, England
pros:
-Great pay (especially for someone who is under 21)
-Very flexible - managers are happy to accommodate any shift pattern
-Friendly team, good company culture
-Plenty of training and support offered 
-Easy to move up to Store manager - Head Office is keen to promote as many people as possible as long as they show initiative and good work ethics.
cons:
Not as good if you are thinking of moving above Store Manager, as the company only seems to hire non-BP specialists for the higher roles (Note: This concerns BP Retail UK - I do not know what the case is for BP Oil). 

Can be a little frustrating if you are the kind of person who takes work seriously, as there is sometimes a lack of enthusiasm towards working amongst many workers.

pros: I have chosen to work for BP Angola for good reputation they had at the market at that time. It was well organised and with high interest in the development and care of the employee. More attention to the safety and high observation for any task carried out.
cons: Arrogance is the most. I found most of the leader and manages to be such arrogant to the juniors and even to the humbles seniors officers — a proper code of conduct written on paper but lousy application in practice.

review_title: Great company, excellent flexible work arrangements
pros:
- Very supportive in terms of flexible working arrangements. I've been on maternity leave twice during my tenure with BP and both times they have been extremely supportive in my return to work to accommodate my family commitments. 
- great benefits & perks e.g fuel discounts, 5 weeks annual leave, excellent salary plus bonuses, etc
- great people
cons:
- large bureaucratic company as expected from a global oil company
- too much complex processes for simple tasks / too much red tape
- very competitive and limited career opportunities for particular areas of the business

pros: Company has good benefits (good 401k match, pension, decent health care). Cafeteria on site. Allow for flexible work hours (not REQUIRING 8-4 or something like that).
cons: Due to the decrease in oil prices recently, the company has made significant cuts and is more concerned with the shareholders than employees. Employees (particularly lower level) really get shafted and treated like crap/like they're throwaway

pros:
As an employee I'd say BP provides a competitive salary and benefits package. BP looks after staff wellbeing with perks like health care and free staff canteen. Flexible work life balance is catered for with ability to work from home. 
Great training offers.
cons:
As a shareholder, the value destruction which has occurred to the businesses equity value is difficult pill to swallow.  
Decisions are also made at glacial speed making it hard to get initiatives moving. 
Sometimes difficult to progress career as there is an emphasis upon development of individual networks which benefits some folks more than others.

review_title: Great Company....some leaders should not be leaders
pros: Great place to work, great work life balance, great benefits, good pay.  Excellent people, smart, hard working (for the most part).
cons: Some leaders are promoted through internal politics/favoritism rather than merit. This leads to lots of ups and downs every time a change is done at the helm.  Right now, some leaders in a few business units are destroying these business units due to their incompetence and arrogance. Very limited forward view and short sighted strategies.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Milton Keynes, England
pros: I have the petrol station just two minutes  from home. Free staff  coffee.  50% discount on your break food. Paid breaks.
cons: Not enough staff so they push you to do more tasks every time . Minimum rate. Staff not  qualified enough because there is a lot of online  training  but no practical. Having to wear safety  boots all the times (that's  the worst part, I'm  thinking in leave because it was hard enough).

review_title: Great Company but losing good people
pros: Full of talented and good people, many of whom are focused on doing a great job. Good opportunities to work with people across the organisation.
cons: Losing it's way at the moment. Organisation is very much focused on its individual business areas and not enough working together and moving talent around the organisation. Hence losing good people in one area when there's been good roles for them in other parts of the company. Available jobs are normally filled by who people know rather than with the right skills.

review_title: A very good company, not perfect, but full of potential.
pros:
Good people. Professional atmosphere. Extremely environmentally and safety minded.
BP supervisors treat people fairly. I've not had the best experiences with HR, however. I generally view HR as evil. A lot of us do.

BP has great potential. We are at a pivotal period. The next 2 years will be very telling as to whether or not we can become the best, or merely remain a profitable company that continues to stand in the shadow of Shell and Exxon.

My hope is on Tony Hayward -- he has a hell of a task in front of him. I wish him the best.
cons:
Pay is a bit low compared to competitors. This is evidenced by a high turn-over rate in the last two years as many BP employees have gone to work for better paying oil companies.

We have a new CEO (on the corporate level) -- Tony Hayward. He is in a tough position, as BP stock has been seriously out-performed by Exxon and other competitors. Tony is big on making "every dollar count". This is good, but we've also witnessed some sweeping changes that seem to save money up front, but are costing us down the road. 

Gain share (VPP) is now a forced ranking system. Every year, ten percent of all BP employees will be sh!t holed and receive absolutely no gain share or cost of living raise. I would love to know  the Einstein that came up with this idea. If ten percent of your employees deserve nothing, then get rid of them!!! Don't make them disgruntled by keeping them on but humiliating them. One day, someone will go postal over this stupid policy.

review_title: If you not into the politics of a large oil company stay away
pros: Boardless opportunities exist within this company. However, if you don't fit in the culture here one will sink fast. Furthermore, it may become difficult to move up the leader. If you would like to gain strong operations competence this is the place for you.
cons: BP's management workforce is highly competitive living no room for mistakes. This can sometimes cause employees with great potential to hold back. The workforce is highly educated leaving less room for average joes. It is almost impossible to move into upper management without a college education. In other words hard work alone just will not get it.

pros:
- Work well paid
- Good work / life balance
- Friendly colleagues
cons:
- Is run as a collection of small companies rather than a single company, so the left hand never knows what the right hand is doing which leads to a lot of ineffeciency; long term strategy is patchy as a result
- Unless you work for the exploration and production side you will always feel like, and be treated, like a poor cousin

review_title: Relaxed work environment, take care of employees.
pros: The oil business is quite a slow and relaxed culture. They make a lot of money and the work is not too crazy. People are professional and they take care of employees, although the pay could have been better (I worked in wholesale and retail fuels, the less sexy side of the business, i.e. "downstream").
cons: The pay could have been better. Things took a long time to get done. It was not as exciting in the downstream business.

pros: Large organization with great people for the most part.  Lots of opportunity to grow your career with strong company values.  Safety is really important and I learned so much about how to use safety tips on the job.
cons: People are not valued.  Profits are the most important item to the company.  You can grow your career but keep your job network because you will need it once your department is cut.

job_title: Human Resources Senior Advisor in Luanda, Luanda
pros: BP is a great company they treat people well and respect work life balance. Opportunities are opened to all who commit and demonstrate capability. The company focus on the full package rather than on base salary alone. They operate in many countries so there is opportunity for mobilisation, but it's not a guarantee.
cons: It has been thru many changes lately in terms of structure but with the aim to make it a better and more efficient company. You will need to cope well with change and adapt in order to be successful.

pros: Benefits are stellar, including 401(k) and pension plan.  Salary is competitive for the industry.  There is significant growth potential into the middle ranks if you're willing to switch your career path around, and be willing to move around the country a lot (especially to Houston).
cons: Management is very disconnected from day-to-day operations; you won't hear from them unless there's a significant problem.  Policies are created with little to no input from the front line workers and therefore are overly burdensome and ineffective.  Too much emphasis is placed on process and paperwork rather than results.  Much time is spent on administrative tasks instead of value-added work.  Requires excessive hours (expect 50-60 per week) just to keep up.

review_title: Good place to work if you don't get caught up in office politics
job_title: Software Engineer in Texas City, TX

review_title: Tough luck charlie outfit.  Several disasters, none the fault of 99% but impacting everyone.

Management who are completely out of touch with reality and vastly over-paid which creates a counter productive them and us culture. pros:
Guided by the Values and behavior which pretty much shaped the employee- employer relation.
Flexi and less controlling. An excellent place for fresh grad to boast their CV. A good place for retired or ladies with family commitment. Job scope is very specific and less require of brain power.

Stakeholders from other center have the tendency to treat the KL team as a call center or 'low life' kind of workers as if we are less intelligence compare to them. Salary freeze doesn't cut across all level with higher level workers being rewarded.

pros: Well Pay. Long contracts. Large conglomerate with a truly global mindset, the minute you begin working for BP you are exposed to a different thinking, a mindset that encompasses different cultures and encourages you to adapt your style to others globally. BP does not encourage a blame culture and massively encourages people 'getting on' with each other at all costs, they encourage values such as courage, pride and learning. BP has a huge online catalogue of processes and ways of working - incredible tool.
cons: BP can be incredibly political, everyone knows everyone and has been around for a very long time. Decision making can take quite long given it being a large corporate. Too many pretty presentations with less focus on substance and delivery.

review_title: 12 year employee hired directly out of college

review_title: The good, the bad and the ugly.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Great place to work and retire

Close to home

Possibility of owning BP shares through your paycheck

review_title: Great place to learn and get a deep perspective on the industry
pros: BP is a great place to start a career. They will train you, expose you to many different aspects/places in the E&P world, and provide you with the tools to succeed in your job. BP has so many different producing areas in their portfolio that you gain a wide range of skills over a very short time frame.
cons: Very large company so things move very slowly. It takes a long time to accomplish anything and that can be frustrating at times. If you do work at BP make sure you are proactive in everything you do, from your technical training to your work... otherwise you can become a number and that does you no good.

pros:
Interned twice at BP, went full time. Now working elsewhere. Got fired for something I deserved to be fired for.

If you get an offer at BP, take it. Period. The work environment is so amazing that it sounds too good to be true to your friends. Big projects, big money, big opportunities. Just incredible. I never met a single jerk at BP. People were willing to put down their work and help you so often. Great gym, great campus, just awesome.
cons: The only con is that the HR department drags their legs on everything. They make promises they won't keep, but that's honestly pretty common at Fortune 500s. DO NOT LET THESE CLOWNS KEEP YOU AWAY FROM THIS AMAZING COMPANY!

pros: Friendly team and management in store with good pay and benefits. Very relaxed atmosphere and huge range of shifts avaliable.
cons: I feel compelled to warn others about the incredibly draining, stupid, beaurocratic "e learning" bp force you to do. I have just finished 25 hours of glitchy infuriating online "training". All of which could easily be compiled into a single 2 hour interactive quiz but instead is dragged out with repeated messages and no option to skip past any slides or videos, the slides have a narrator which turns, what would be a 5 second read and move to the next slide, into a 2 minute narration with no option other than to sit and wait through it. I understand health and safety is important, therfore you do not have to tell me 14000 times in some kind of propoganda format. After finishing this e-learning it is fair to say I have never felt more ready to die.

pros: None that I can think of. ...well, you get paid on time.
cons: 7 - 10 day shifts are common. You'll be expected to cancel your holiday leave, which was booked months in advance, with just a few days notice from management. Shifts and days off are changed at very short notice. It's very rare to get two days off in a row. You'll be expected to do unpaid over time everyday. I do 30 mins to 1 hour a day. I start at 5.15 am. Work every weekend. You're expected to have 3 pairs of hands - get food out on time whilst making customer drinks, sandwiches, doing temperature checks, serving on the till amongst other things. You rarely get help. 2 people are needed in the cafe. You'll be moaned at if things are done late. Management are clueless. There is no career for you working in Wild Bean Cafe.

Good and efficient internal processes and IT infrastructure. 
Majority of colleagues nice and helpful, knowing what team work actually means.

Bureaucracy (they are working on this but we'll see if it works out)
Over analysis of issues instead of just going and doing it!

pros:
Excellent compensation
Fantastic people

Great opportunities for career growth
Global company
cons: Sometimes the work/life balance can be rough, particularly the higher in the organization you go.  It can feel at times that you are expected to be be available via email 24/7.

pros: Pay and benefits. There's also a good history of innovation and a reputation for excellence that -- if the company can regain it -- will serve employees well.

Another downside for American employees is the growing emphasis on London leadership at the expense of a strong U.S. management presence.  At the same time this is happening, the company is shutting down (for financial reasons) opportunities for U.S. leaders to take expat assignments in London.

review_title: Good company to work for career-wise

cons: The company has poor human relations management. It is all  about profit and don't care about employee welfare. job_title: IT Project Manager in London, England

pros: Good and nice colleagues in the company.  Most people are willing to help each other, though there are exceptions.

In some areas very limited project to work on or even no new project coming in.   That is why a lot of good people chose to leave ---  the future is very uncertain for the company.

pros:
Adapting Global Standards and setting upfront goals make life more crispy and spicy in moments working over with BP. I would say Seriousness and Safety can make you a Global leader.

-bonus structure is not motivating as it is largely determined by the success of the company as a whole and is difficult to affect as an individual

review_title: Good company to work for if you play your politics right.

cons: Too much favoritism, promotion of some real pin-heads

review_title: A company that values the safety and happiness of their employees

You can usually transfer to a different position after a couple of years.  Excellent relocation package for qualifying employees.
cons: There are some very complex or cumbersome processes to deal with at BP, which can make it hard to get work done in a cost effective manner.  Technology upgrades can be slow and painful due to the size of the company.

review_title: My experience is that BP is overall a good company to work for.
pros: Good benefits (401k with company matching up to 6%), pension, insurance, educational assistance, training, etc. Some groups have 9/80 work schedule and others may allow for other flexible working schedules.
cons: As is with large global corporations, there is so much bureaucracy to get things done. Due to inner politics, management sometimes dictate whether a project will "succeed" regardless of what that state of "success" may look like.

review_title: Wants to be exxon and this could be the best thing that can keep this place floating.
pros: Good benefits and work life balance. Great people!
cons: HR is going to force all to leave. Upper management is tribal. Huge amount of process and policy since the spill and think the best way is to follow the Exxon model. Motto is to layoff senior people and train juniors, a item that was listed as a reason for the spill...the best thing can happen to these guys is to get bought by exxon or another that can manage business.

review_title: Lack of Challenge and Burdened by Bureacracy/Inefficient Process
pros:
Work-life balance. 
Benefits on-par with industry/competitors.
Flexible working arrangements.

Here there's generally has slow pace of work, burdened by long winded processes/concept appraise stages or people who generally don't have a clue or interest in what they're doing.

pros: Diversified work force - independence of taking decisions, satisfaction of achievement. It takes time, but eventually you are recognized for your efforts.
cons: Too much process to follow. Not enough time given to master one process before moving on to the next one. restriction of employee hours you can use to run sites. Sometimes promises made are not followed through or kept up with. Wage base of hourly at site employees not at par with competitors in the similar field.

review_title: BP - changing times, but not a bad place to work

cons: typical big corporate bs and lack of customer understanding at senior levels, too internally focused

It encourages skip level dialogues and drives excellence in what you do.
cons: Process, the process is god and it seems to the be the proverbial tail.

job_title: Process Operator in Kingston upon Hull, England

You dont feel hounded by management all the time and they give you space to do your job effectively. If you can dodge the bullet til retirement day then you will be relatively well off in retirement.
cons: People have to reapply for jobs every few years. Constant specualtion about breaking up R&M and E&P. Share price is a bit low recently (but then thats a problem people without good share schemes dont have I suppose)

pros: Work Life Balance, they care about their employees, good not great compensation. Good 1st level leadership,.  Overall good company, great company to start career and great company to finish career, not very good to spend your prime.
cons: Horrible and worthless HR, extremely political and Bureaucratic, horrible upper level management, no direction or strategy. , emphasizes commercial roles instead of technology / engineering roles. Does not focus on technology, engineering, or innovation.

review_title: Good pay, benefits, very weak leaders

cons:

pros: Excellent pay and benefits, compressed working week, reasonably relaxed working environment with good camaraderie between colleagues.
cons: Morale is currently very low.  Most people appear to be staying only because the pay is so good and opportunities in the oil industry scarce at the moment.
