Very old fashioned company - currently focused on modernizing but held back by an aging, mostly British management.

job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Saint Albans, England
pros: Great training, friendly staff and good management. Can progress into management roles if want to. Employee benefits are good. Good for part time.
cons: Hours are not sociable 6-2 and 3-11. Should have better hours given. However biggest issue is not paid enough for amount of work done/completed in a shift.  Bad for full time job not enough pay and can make u very tired and unhappy if working over 30 hours  for example due to multiple roles in a shift for a small store which has  marks and Spencer’s food.

review_title: If you're an engineer, BP is a great place to work.   If you're a corporate staff member, not so much!
job_title: Human Resources Advisort  in Warrenville, IL
pros:
Benefits and compensation above average in the marketplace
For technical functions, there's room to grow and learn.
Best place to be is Houston, TX, as the company is shifting its corporate presence there.
cons:
No work-life balance
Constant reorganization and change
The only division that is respected is Exploration and Production.   If you're in one of the other divisions, you work in daily fear of downsizing and divestment.

review_title: Throughout my years at BP I obtained great experience, but was increasingly undervalued & limited in career advancement.
pros: BP offers excellent benefits and due to its global reach there are opportunities to gain international experience if desired, although the expat program has been severely reduced from what it used to be.
cons: They do not have a grasp on what constitutes good leadership qualities.  The pay is not competitive, especially if you have been with the company a long time.

pros: Better salary range compared to other shared service center in Malaysia. The job offers some flexibility where employees are allowed to have 2 work from home day weekly and flexible working hours.
cons: Weak management team, poor planning in executing big scale projects, lack of process standardization and simplification. Lack of synergy and does not give employees sense of belonging.

pros: Structured development programme for new graduates; training opportunities available along with on the job support and mentorship; international outlook; good people and considerate management; excellent work-life balance
cons: lacking performance culture; rigid career paths (i.e. difficult to move across functions and regions); bureaucracy related to a big organisation

review_title: Dull with slow progress lots of deadwood
pros: Work life balance, £5 lunch allowance daily, plenty of benefits to choose from, paid maternity/paternity pay, opportunity to take courses, big name on CV
cons: Deathly slow career progression with IST being full of micromanagers. Lots of internal politics with many layers of middle management justifying their existence. Many of the old guard hanging on for the last few years until they can claim their final salary pension (doesn't exist for new employees). Very very adverse to change and the company has zero appetite for expansion or risk.

review_title: Beats working outside in the heat and humidity of Houston.
pros: It's a salary. If you are motivated and say yes enough times, you'll get ahead.  The old pre-merger BP would be "Ready, ..., Fire"  "Ready, ..., Fire".   The old pre-merger Amoco was "Ready, Aim, ..."   "Ready, Aim, ...".   Eventually, we will get to "Ready, Aim, Fire".
cons: Too much process. Retirement plan was much better for heritage Arco, Amoco and Vastar staff.

review_title: Progressive and could really benefit from empowerment
pros: Equal opportunities employer with opportunities to work and develop personally on the global stage. Strong corporate and brand values that tries to do its best.
cons: Size and bureaucracy can sometimes stifle growth and ambition, in addition to killing innovation because of the perceived lower risk strategy. This can lead to frustration because of slow decision making and a lack of empowerment and trust of employees - despite the strong human capital base.

review_title: Slow moving for a high performer
pros: Benefits and 401k, salary, social network, volunteer opportunities and corporate events, support for education, nice facilities, global company, career opportunities are available (albeit a bit slow), support for community.
cons:
Bureaucratic, lack of systematic processes, negative/whining culture, poor systems, constant change that drags on and on. Performance ratings are totally subjective. Lack of personal accountability (lends to lack of decision making).

A good place to develop, not sure it's a good place to build an entire career. The culture and bureaucracy alone are enough to add ample (unnecessary) stress. BP has a long ways to go to become a mature, efficient company.

pros: BP pays well for the work that you do. They have one of the best benefits packages that I've seen. When they are making money they like to spend it and bonuses almost always get paid.
cons:
BP is a poorly managed company, their safety track record speaks for itself. Though they advertise that they are focused on improving, leadership has done little to change the culture. They've been in constant "transformation" for the last 5-8 years. Also just recently, at least in the US they have been making it more challenging to participate in agile working arrangements. Leadership has not eliminated agile working, they have just communicated a message that does not promote it.   

Because they pay well senior managers tend not to leave, and most are waiting for a severance package to do so. This leads to very little long term opportunity.

pros: Lots of opportunity in upstream.  Large challenging projects to work on with global support and implications.  Moving to the forefront in technology in the oil and gas business.  Diverse company with a variety of technical knowledge available.
cons: Large company with government type bureaucracy.  Sometimes hard to get things done.  There are a lot of silos where target metrics may not match the overall goal.  Depending on job, work/life balance may be an issue.  Sometimes mutual respect is talked about, but it is not fully implemented.

review_title: Great company, my have had recent reputational issues, but solid on its treatment of people
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Cleveland, OH
pros: Lots of development, VERY performance focused, stable. Mobility helps you advance. SAFETY IS A KEY PRIORITY to get right if you're with this company. Was open to transparency long before expected at other companies. Good policy structures. I never felt out of bounds for asking questions if done the right way, nor was I pressured to do things unethical/out of bounds while I was there.
cons: Definite internal "Class distinction" toward upstream vs downstream business segments, sometimes in seeking incremental safety performance, things got somewhat inpractical.

review_title: Very good company that cares about it's people
pros:
- Great opportunities for the employees to develop their skills
- Large pool of very highly skilled staff to work with and learn from
- Great depth of resources and tools to work with
- very good benefits
- generally very nice people to work with that are team oriented
cons:
- Can be stressful
- A lot of process
- Can be slow to move due to size of company

pros: I believe that the management strives to be fair and tries to do the right thing even in these trying times for the oil industry.
cons: Lots of jobs being lost in the il industry due to the falling price of oil. This combined with the higher lifting cost of offshore oil puts the companies financial situation on shaky ground.

pros: The work environment offers great work life balance.  The benefits are well beyond what most companies offer, so that offers quite a bit of security.
cons: Though the benefits are great, the company reorganizes every year and a half.  That means that 25% of your time in any given role is spent worrying about whether or not you will have a job in four months.  This is a male dominated company.  The women who tend to excel at BP ingratiate themselves to male senior management or tend to have male characteristics (which doesn't mean they are unqualified, it just puts other women at a disadvantage).  I had several consecutive years of "Exceeds Expectations" evaluations only to watch my career stagnate.  No thanks.

pros: The pay is good compared to other SSC's/BSC's in Budapest. They also provide lots of extras; company phone, home office and extra activities.
cons:
The company almost propagandizes their values, which are clearly visible on the surface but not on a personal level. So when working, and if you want to excel it is expected to constantly and mindlessly display the company values. 

And although the values themselves represent a high moral standard and there is nothing wrong with the values, they are being used to cut out any form of creativity or people who think for themselves.

pros: Good pay, benefits, and for those looking for a place to hide and not have to do much to earn those benefits there are a reasonable number of places where this can happen.
cons: Too many people killing themselves to deliver while too many are skating by barely working, even at the executive level. Feast or famine in terms of expectations and deliverables, how they are communicated, expected, or supported.

review_title: BP is (will be) Losing Good Employees
pros: Balancing work and life hours is fairly important.  But, because BP is based in the UK, we sometimes work on US Holidays (i.e. Labor Day, Indepedence Day).  Stress diversity (this can be both good and bad).
cons: Non-competative salaries; slow-moving with everything; poor internal planning.  Because many employees have been there for years and plan to stay until they retire, there's no incentive to go the extra mile. Many of the employees with 20+ years are on the average 50-50 years old.  BP seriously needs new, fresh ideas from younger people.

review_title: Good experience personally, varies greatly by job
pros: Market facing staff (traders, schedulers, market analysts, and commercial development) all make good money and are in demand throughout the industry with skills and knowledge that every other trading competitor desires. Great location downtown with great office and casual dress. Really good benefits (7% 401k matching) and a PENSION!
cons: British employees from main office regularly come over and take the most desirable jobs. Lack of senior american management (don't let the Dudley hire fool ya). Can get pigeon holed into a narrow career focus and therefore can have narrow work experience. Being a large company, it also suffers from the usual bureacracy.

pros:
Fair Pay / Benefits
Challenging / Engaging Projects and Opportunities to be a Part of
Open to Professional Development Opportunities (certifications, continuing education, etc)
Large Company that Provides Many Opportunities for Networking (both in and out of the company)
I have had positive experiences with direct line managers - professional and supportive
cons:
Promotion Opportunities / Career Paths Not Transparent
Work / Life Balance not Always Respected 
Top Down Leadership Style from Site / Company Leadership Team (disconnected from the do-ers)

job_title: IT Project Manager in London, England
pros: Great company to work for - good benefits package and most areas Agile working concept is being adopted whic helps balance personal and work life.
cons: Hard to progress internally. Internal hiring process is completely frauded. Internal positions are given to those who are not qualified but were good enough selling themselves. Unless you get an internal sponsor, promotions and/or career progression are impossible. Due to this system, in certain areas you see very poor management and completely lack of leadership.

review_title: Time to set a path and stick with it
pros: -Good pay and benefits (401k, Medical, etc.)
cons:
The company and functions need to stick with a direction. It has become really confusing on what direction we are going as employees observe contradictions all the time. 
The "control" organization has become cumbersome and frustrating, to say the least. 
Career development has become a real issue for myself and team as I am encouraged to have my employees become "jacks of all trades, master of none".
The culture has shifted towards who you know and less on merit, which has made it difficult for employees to feel motivated.

review_title: The good, the bad and the bureaucratic
job_title: Process Engineer in City of London, England
pros: Good early development opportunities and training.  Very bright and interesting people.  There are parts of the organisation which are very well led.   There is a real opportunity to take advantage of the current market conditions to become leaner and fitter.
cons: Very bureaucratic and slow moving so it makes it difficult to get things done in such a conservative culture.  There seems to be an air of head in the sand amongst many people - maybe it's a result of too much change, too many times.

review_title: Working at BP isn't so bad, but the crazy management and organization of the company leaves it vulnerable to more risk.
pros: Benefits are great - pay, all insurances, bonuses, company matching, vacation, are above most companies; but about equal to other oil  gas companies.  Supports diversity and inclusion quite well.
cons: Too many reorganizations; big emphasis on who you know rather than what you can do.  Seems that it doesn't matter if you do a good job -  more important than doing a good job is who you know in the company.  Must have the personality to socialize and network quite a bit in order to be successful.

pros: BP is a truly international company with lots of opportunities to work with colleagues from around. BP hires extremely intelligent and competent people, and co-worker are always willing to help out when asked. Work-life balance and benefits are also hard to beat.
cons: Recent divestments, budget cuts, and layoffs have changed BP's US operations substantially over the last few years. Long-term career growth and opportunities are no longer what they used to be.

pros:
1.  Have established procedures for safety and operations and have implemented assurance plans.
2.  Pay is ok and benefits are very good.
cons:
1.  Management seems to micro-manage costs and employees and misses big opportunities for savings and success because of this.
2.  Selling large number of assets over the past decade and struggling to compete because of back office cost per asset.

review_title: Great atmosphere with people who make u I want to worn your hardest and enjoy doing it!
pros: You always have someone there  to help you if you don't know what to do yourself. Which is incredibly helpful and encouraging.
cons: The food at BP is very limited according to wether it is Halal or not so for people who do follow the religion of Islam will list days have to chose the vegaterian meal as a default.

pros: modern office. Pay per position is not bad compared to similar functions at other companies around. On the spot bonuses. Internal trainings offered are high standard. Strong brandname
cons: a lot of movement at the base and difficult to move up. Salary is based on what you negotiate at entry not at worked delivered afterwards, so it might happen somebody who brings much less to the table than you earns more. The kindergarten mentality can really be annoying at times.

job_title: Shipping & Receiving Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: BP was a positive and professional company to work for and I'm proud to have been part of there organization. BP was fair, honest was knowledgeable in the alternative energy field.
cons: There are no cons other than BP had made the decision to exit alternative energy in the US which effected about 450 employees.

pros: One of the best companies that I have ever worked for.  They beleive in their core values, putting safety and family first., s well as giving back to the community. There is always an abundance of resources to get any job completed successfully, and always a team environment to work in, as well as a good atmosphere.  Nine-Eighty work schedule.
cons: When some of the past incidents took place, more Btitts starting being placed in management roles and it really started changing the company.

pros:
-Great pay and benefits 
-Lots of employee "perks"
-Some of the smartest individuals in the Oil & Gas industry
-Really focused on the future of the energy industry and bringing cleaner/greener energy to the world
-The scale of what BP does and you do on your team is fascinating
cons:
-Such a big company it can be difficult to navigate at times
-Slow moving x1000
-As part of the Rotational Program for recent college grads your geographic location is very much up in the air and can quickly change

review_title: Why it sucks to work for BP as an engineer?
job_title: Operations Support Mechanical Engineer/ Project Engineer in London, England
pros: Chance to get a wide range of experience and to be exposed to all kinds of equipment. Large budget for training during the project phase. Opportunity to build a good business network during your career, to experience different aspects of mechanical engineering while working with contractors, which in turn may help you in finding your perfect next job.
cons: Too much politics. Unfair promotions and very poor senior leadership. Failure to understand the importance of core engineering positions. Double standards between different assets in terms of benefits, salaries, promotions and career opportunities.

review_title: Great learning opportunity, but time to move on.
pros: The benefits offered by BP are great and there are opportunities to move to another location if you desire.  There are plentiful training opportunities and it is relatively easy for someone to work their way up the ladder, which creates some of the problems within the company.
cons: The organization is in constant change and is suffering from poor management.  Most leadership are interested in satisfying their managers and everything is all about making them look good.  Management is not focused on actually improving the company, but are focused on checking boxes and looking good.   Morale within the workforce is also very low right now.

pros: Good compensation and benefits. The company started with good ideas about renewable sources of energy but abandon those plans very soon.
cons: There is no stability in BP as it used to be. The company's structure is like a pyramid and the top managers do not communicate with the people doing the actual work. They relied on middle managers that mostly want to enforce what they are told to do without listening to the consequences. The company is very slow in reacting and cannot compete with much faster smaller companies.

pros:
- Great opportunities for early careerists 
- Autonomy to seek areas for improvement within the business but also the resources and capabilities to exact change
- Extremely competitive salary
- Strong emphasis on creating a welcoming culture
cons:
- As with any LSO, implementing change takes a very long time and requires a lot of influencing
- Witnessed qualified colleagues be overlooked for promotions and the roles being offered to external candidates

pros: Opportunities for seastaff to come ashore and into the wider group. Seastaff have a good chance of completing a tour of duty in the same or a better state than before - not the same elsewhere. Emphasis on safety is strongly led at the opertional unit level (on the ships!).
cons:
Not much emphasis on paper being ok - not operations! Old priority was safe transportation of hydrocarbons and reducing risk to bp as a whole - now it's about maximising profit and cutting costs.
Sometimes it seems that QA applies to the ships - not to the office. This may mean open communication is reduced.

review_title: Great place to work, be prepared to fight to stay.
pros: Schedule flexibility, open envirnment, williness to share new ideas.
cons: Bureaucratic methods to get those new ideas in place, too many discussions and not enough action. Mirred in 'old school' operations beliefs from those who have been with the company since the amoco/ Sohio days, and believe their way is still the best way.  Multiple reorganizations, about every two years.  Not enough consistency in leadership staying around for mopre than a couple years in role.

pros: Good training for recent graduates who are accepted onto this graduate scheme in BP's integrated supply and trading division in canary wharf, london.
cons: To become an actual professional trader for BP you must first pass what is called the assessed traders test, so even if you complete the 3 years of training there is a chance you may not become qualified (this is rare, however, and i think you can resit it)

pros: Good initial training, nice attitude from other stores management teams
cons: Way underpaid for the amount of work and responsibilities asked, the hours are unsocial, the schedules are unfair, if staff call in sick managers are made to cover wether they can/like it or not, no appreciation, after the initial training you are left to the mercy of any store manager who may or may not want to help you reach your full potential, overtime is not paid but you are expected to do it

review_title: One of the best managed Companies I have worked for.  Very open minded with a concern of  Professional Intergity.
pros: Dedicated to best practices supported by a strong research center.  Maintained a great program for professional development offering a number of schools, seminars and training for value additions through team effort and formation.
cons: Amoco could have improved on technology development as were some of the other majors.  I have had experience with Shell where I found an intense aptitude for technical formation and incentive for rewarding technical input.

pros: Great professional staff and work environment with really good benefits
cons: Few opportunities to rotate and no changes in management even if they are doing bad. Portfolio is shrinking!

pros:
Renewed focus on development with strong leadership/business engagement and sound governance.
Driving increased use of technology and real focus on what is required.
Global role allows great opportunities for growth.
Great collaboration across the group learning functions.
cons:
Resources are stretched so must rigorously prioritise.
Need to more broadly communicate the offer in a way that is clear, concise and understandable.
Working effectively in a virtual way across regions and time-zones is not easy for some and requires constant attention and effort.

pros: Been working at BP for a little under a year now, and so far it's be a great experience. The people are great, and there appears to be a lot of opportunities for advancement.
cons: I really haven't had any negative experiences personally while working here, but I've heard from my colleagues who've been at BP for a long time that things used to be even better before the oil prices tanked.

review_title: Company with potential but needs to clean house of so many layers of management who cannot make a decision
pros:
BP is a global company.  If you are moble, you many opportunities around the world. 

BP has a good compensation program.
cons:
A lot of red tape to get anything done.  
The company is very risk adverse after Texas City disaster.  
They do not do a good job at developing there people.  
Advancement is very tied to networking and who you know.

review_title: Working at the refinery has been challenging and rewarding.
pros: The people are great and BP respects a balance between work and life. It's always about people first and production second. I'm proud to work here. I always feel supported by management and my opinions are valued.
cons: Since BP is divesting it's southern California operations and we don't know who will buy the refinery, times are uncertain.  Right now, we are all in a holding pattern. many things will likely change with new ownership, which is expected by the end of 2012.

review_title: BP downsize every six months in all parts of the organization.
pros: Salary and benefits are very competive for work in the industry. Great place to work if you are a workaholic.
cons: Overworked due to large staff cuts.  People moved to new roles and unsure of direction and responsibilities. No work life balance. Reorganizations trapp employees into roles and prohibit transfers into other parts of the organization.  The only way out of USPL is to leave the company.

review_title: Hectic, fun, and full of opportunities
pros:
* Work with some of the industries brightest
* Flexible work schedule
* Better work/home balance than average
* Upper quartile pay and benefits
* Large scale of operations, seems like the projects you work on have a big impact
* Good corporate culture, especially from R&D folks
* Shareholder friendly
* Team atmosphere.  People typically like to pull together when you can get the backing.
cons:
* Complex sets of engineering rules and practices makes any project implementation an exercise in research
* A C.Y.A. attitude among employees and management.  This is both good and bad.  I makes you be very thorough when designing new equipment, but that thoroughness is done so that if something does not work like it should then you have documents proving you were (should be) right.   "I designed this (heat exchanger... whatever) to API, TEMA and BP standards so I don't know why it's not working.  It's not my fault."  Not a totally bad attitude to have because due to it 99% of things work great.
* Company is in a major state of flux with employees always wondering what the BU will do next to repair its image.  As employees, we are ready to move on and get this dark cloud over us gone so we can get back to safe, compliant, and profitable business operations.
* Desire to be the best, but often throws lots of money to fix issues (behaviors and process) with less than optimal return on capital deployed.
* More office politics (read... promotion and career molding) than I personally like.  There are some people that if you cross them they can stop your career dead in its tracks.  We have a saying that we work in a "glass house", so don't throw stones and don't try to hide anything because it will all come out and you'll look like a fool.
* Everything you work on is a high priority and was needed yesterday.  Always shuffling priorities.

review_title: Great Values, mid-senior management is poor, no work / life balance, no career growth except for ordained few
pros: Good pay, most employees are dedicated / work hard and a great set of Company Values and goals. Senior management has a good plan that gets lost in the empire building / personal agenda of the middle managers.
cons: Like many other reviews the middle management is weak and don't live by the Values. There is a back biting style and no work / life balance. Promotions / jobs based on popularity. "High Potential" employee program for select employees leads to these entitled few getting the glory while the rest of the employees actually do the work. Managers who affairs with there subordinates / harass woman / are bullies get promoted instead of fired.

pros:
BP has many smart, terrific people and, in general, a cooperative, collaborative work environment.  They work at getting work/life balance right and generally do a good job of it.
Good Pay and benefits.  BP facilities around the world are nice and comfortable places to work
cons: Since the Gulf Spill BP seems to have lost its way.  They are in constant reorganization creating ongoing confusion as to how people and departments are to work together.  The complexity of the organization makes decision making slow, iterative and confusing.

review_title: It's a bit here and there
pros: Good wage, good contract and some friendly people who work there and there are always paid breaks.
cons: There is extremely bad management, they are mismatched and treat their members of staff like they are nothing.

job_title: Division Order Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: The workload definitely taught our group a thing or two about multitasking.  Conversations with industry counterparts lead me to believe that analyst responsibilities at BP encompass a broader range of duties than most which can be valuable when job searching. Benefits are also good.
cons: Management does not recognize employees and every move made is for their own gain rather than for the team they lead.  Snide and demeaning remarks have been made with no repercussion.  They lack the knowledge and experience of their employees which creates resentment when their employees are doing 10 times the amount of work.

pros: Good, caring internal culture. Although a little subject to role/team, most people are forward thinking, want to make a positive contribution and are ready to help each other achieve their goals. Good work-life balance and some teams are also good at encouraging flexible working. Great pay and benefits for engineers.
cons: Slow and bureaucratic. Impossible to have the career that you want as you're more likely to be told what you'll do. If what you want what the company wants then you'll do great. Lots of people around who are okay but not particularly happy with their jobs.

pros:
Flexibility in hours/ shift times 
Public holiday pay is okay
Great environment to gain experience in both retail and hospitality simultaneously
cons:
Poor career development options - can progress to assistant manager then to site manager but I went to assistant manager and went back to a CSR as it was not worth it.
Minimum wage.
Weekend pay is not that great- same rates for Saturday and Sunday.
Head office and corporate managers have no idea what it is like to work in a store or serve customers so some ideas or targets they have can be ridiculous

review_title: Do not work there unless you are the old boy's club

Work life balance
lay back
No overtime work
many opportunities to improve the process
If you are talented and put of the club, you can do a lot
cons:
Old boy's club
many mid level manager are old thinking
resistant to change, any change (good or bad) will result of loss your job
No transparent, no share information, hinding results 
Say one thing, do opposite 
No place for minority and woman to grow

review_title: Large company with a focus on work / life balance and safety
pros: BP has great benefits. From talking to friends, family and co-workers, they are some of the best around and as such are good reasons to stick with them if you find yourself doing work that you like.
cons: It's hard to stand out in a large company, even if you are going above and beyond what your job entails.

job_title: Integrated Supply and Trading Division in London, England
pros: BP Trading Organisation (IST) was decent and entrepreneurial.  Good benefits and work/life balance.  Strong emphasis on regulatory compliance / CSR / diversity aspects.  I had a sense of decency about senior management, even while the company was going through a period of tremendous stress following the tragic Deepwater Horizon event in the Gulf of Mexico.
cons: Massive scale of the trading operations (multiple major trading floors around the world) gave me a sense that the company was hard to manage and led to inefficiencies and inconsistencies in some areas.  I also felt that the company was somewhat slow to tackle under-performing staff in some cases.

pros: good salary, great benefits, challenging environment. it has health center, cafeteria and fitness club on campus. Engineers do not do lot of calculations , end up reviewing subcontractor work. Opportunity for training and developing management skills.
cons: You need to very proactive stay relevant. Need to have right connections and keep bosses happy to keep job. Reorganizations never end. One after another. seems like that is another way of creating job and the upper management keep relevance.

pros: You get a tonnes of responsibilities front the start and you can gain real work experience that can't be taught in school or in other companies. They hire the best and expect the best but the younger staff sometimes don't get the recognition of the work that they do if they don't speak up.
cons: If you get a bad boss don't expect that your concerns will be heard quickly. Some regions still have issues with dealing with poor middle management and the issues are lost due to fear of lower performance ranking or getting the image of " complainer" among team mates.

review_title: Not Too Bad but Hard to Move Up the Ladder
pros: You need to be totally proactive with your career development.  The company is so huge that you get lost and fall to the bottom.  Make sure that your work is visible to someone in upper middle managment and higher.  Very laid by environment.
cons: There are quite a few "lifers" there with no ambition.  If you are aggressive and want to move up quickly, this place may not be for your.

review_title: Good company but grew too fast and is paying the price
pros: Decent pay & benefits, lots of opportunity to spread your wings if your willing to travel
cons: More bureaucracy than the federal government.    Seems like the company is still trying to sort through the many mergers of late 90's.    Stock options only given to higher levels in the organization.

pros: Flexible working hours (dependent on manager), extra week of annual leave, training and development. Strong corporate brand with global opportunities available mostly at senior levels.
cons: Favours those who can manage up. Very slow to get things moving with multiple layers of decision makers and red tape. A lot of yes men and women who stifle change and innovation. HR are powerless to address workplace psychopaths. The values are not reflected across the business, particularly from senior management that have been at BP too long.

pros: BP promotes minorities and women and has a lot of collective knowledge.  People are nice at BP, but only because their jobs are ultimately too cushy.  It's easy to be nice when you're jobs are fluff and you make fewer executive decisions per person.
cons: Everything happens too slowly, too many processes, too much overhead, too many meetings and trying to follow the functional model just because its a corporate trend when you've become a small operator who's overstaffed is not effective.

pros: BP is a great company to work with. Most boss was the greatest and he was very kind and helpful. They took me out to dinner when a was relocating from Ilinois.
cons: If i could i would have worked in the day time that would have been better. I would loved to have worked more hours but that would not have been good for my health. Overall great company to work for.

pros: Good benefits and pay, friendly co-workers, business-casual dress code, team oriented, very autonomous and fluid decentralized environment. Great facilities in Chicago and Houston - Gym, Wellness Center, Medical/Dental/Vision on-site, Daycare, FEDEX, Café, Starbucks, etc......
cons: Functioning in ambiguity, lack of core process and procedure at times, slow implementation - excessive meetings to make a decision, no org. charts, excessive spending on T&E.

pros:
Benefits Salary Work life balance schedule safety culture environmental culture 
Work load helped reduce stress. Team culture was good and encouraged.
cons: Promotion opportunities were few. No level increase plan existed for engineers who remained in technical role rather than changing to management. 20 year + engineers had the same grade level as 5 year engineers with some difference in salary but not for bonus percentage.

review_title: Good people working with lousy direction from management
job_title: Franchise Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The employees at BP are generally good, talented employees.  Unfortunately the direction from senior management was all over the place, so re-organizations became a yearly event.  If you are a good solid employee that is willing to relocate for the company, however, your job is (usually) safe.  They are pretty good at rewarding performance and recognizing their better employees.  But as the overall company performance continues to decline, it is harder and harder to keep the good people.  And as more good people see the writing on the wall, the more people jump ship...which just leads to a continued decline in talent....it's become a slippery slope.
cons: Because of the declining performance of the company, many jobs have been eliminated and therefore the career paths of many people have become limited.  Anyone coming into the company now won't have the many different options for career growth that used to be available.  In the US, there are really only two places to work now (used to be over five) - Los Angeles or Houston.  Employee morale is pretty much in the toilet now, and it will take a long time before that recovers.  Until senior management gets their act together, it will be hard to see a light at the end of this tunnel.

review_title: For what it is, pretty good. Needs some improvement, but who doesn't?
job_title: Instrument and Controls Technician in Houma, LA
pros: Actually if you work hard and are unrelenting in accomplishing your job, this place has fairly decent opportunities.  Management will at least act like they are listening to you. Management won’t fly of the handle and scream or lose their cool very often, if ever. The company is getting its VPP (variable pay for performance) package to be fairer in rewarding those who work hard and consistently. Hourly people can get a VPP in four different brackets; (a.) under expectations=0% bonus, (b.) meets expectations=7% bonus, (c.) exceeds expectations=17.5% bonus, (d.) exceptional=21% bonus. It is a little more complex than that but, not much and it is pretty fair in a lot of ways.  They match 401k at 7%, administered through Fidelity. The overall resources for work /life balance are pretty great considering the size of the company.  I get four forty hour weeks paid vacation every year, but I work 84 hour weeks offshore so I really get two offshore weeks off every year. They pay $250 towards fitness equipment for you to buy for your home uses every year, plus $300 for participating in other health initiatives through BPhit program. So, I can have six weeks in a row off every year without missing my base check. Nice.  You won’t ever be harassed for taking the time to do the job safely or environmentally friendly. They do have mechanisms in place to report unethical management practices so that you have a form of recourse if they want you to take unnecessary chances or risks. I appreciate the fact that even if they are truly at heart an oil company, they are taking steps to create a greener company.  Overall, I am pretty happy with the company, for what it is and what industry it is in.
cons: It is a big company so they have some trouble with change. You have to really work to get anyone to follow recommendations or listen to advice, but it can be done. More so than many places this one has lots of chiefs, lots of initiatives, lots of programs, and all these lead to lots of paperwork.  The hire in process leaves a lot to be desired. There are many programs that the only way you find out about them is by asking your coworkers, and that is what HR expects. Sometimes it seems that the extraneous programs and initiatives are more important to management than being good at your job. The politically correct speech and business politics have taken hold of BP and sometimes you long for the “good ole days” when you could say what you mean and mean what you say. It seems that it is all about CYA (cover you’re a**), there are the expected politics and ole boy club that characterizes the oil field. Sometimes common sense takes a back seat to London or Houston’s whims. Not that they are all bad but sometimes they seem overblown, over engineered, and under thought. Sometimes the company doesn’t have the time or money to do things right the first time, but we will have it either on the second or third time though. ? I have never known any other schedule but I work offshore and my schedule is 14 days on 14 days off and 12 hour days for the 14 days that I am at work, I think that I would like to try something else. Not BP’s fault, but it is one negative about the job for me.

review_title: It has its ups and downs, but overall a good place to work.
pros: I've been at BP over ten years now. As a long term employee, I have my share of petty gripes about the company. But overall I can't complain. I believe the company genuinely cares about it's employees, the pay and benefits are excellent, and the work-life balance is good. And the people I work with are great.
cons:
In some areas of the business there are still good 'ol boys networks, but it seems like the company is working hard to dismantle them. Unfortunately there are still some mid-level and higher people who are only in their roles because of their network. Sometimes personnel policies can be pushed aside for convenience. For example, even though most roles are supposed to be posted and competitive - and employees are expected to be in a role for at least two years - some employees (one's who are deemed to to be "special" by management) are given the role through "facilitated moves" and the two year rule is ignored. For the rest of us mere mortals, we just have to suck it up. It's not a widespread issue, but it can cause some discontent when someone is given a plum assignment over many other equally qualified people who weren't even given a chance to apply and interview.

One other con is that the company is continuously reorganizing. In the last ten years I've lost track of the number of reorgs. Every time new senior management comes in it seems that the old organization is ineffective and needs to be replaced. It's happening again as I write this.

Pre Spill, Pre sale of EOR retail, I mistakenly accepted a position through a widely known recruiting agency with another East Coast American fortune 500 global energy company for more money. cons:
The company operates in a very reactive manner (and considering there are shattering incidents that seem to occur every so often, that's not a good thing). Currently, oil price is down, and there are job cuts all around (the jobs that were added - but were they necessary? - back when the going was good and crude was high). When the going gets good again, the projects will commence and there will be an influx. While this is normal in any cyclical industry, there are ways to manage this in teams/roles that are justified ALL the time - and don't just come and go, based on financial performance.
This company loves reorganizing and restructuring. The message can be all about alternative energy and environmental compliance one day, and then shift to process safety solely the other - there isn't a balance across all to systematically oversee the entire portfolio through ANY type of market.
Similarly, when I first joined (6.5 years ago), the company was open to moving cross-functionally, as long as you were eager to learn and could prove yourself. Now, there is a significant shift toward specialization, and keeping people in their current track. 
Also, my experience has taught me that proving yourself as a high performer, when early in your career, can sometimes be a double-edged sword. Management won't want to get rid of you, and just keep you in your role.

pros:
Benefits package is still relatively good - defined benefit pension scheme is still competitive, share schemes are worth participating in, and the company car scheme is good once you are senior enough to benefit from it.  In most UK locations you get a free lunch and subsidised or free gym membership.  

The people who work here are generally bright and interesting to work with, although this does not necessarily mean that they are good at running a business - there is a tendency to overcomplicate things.  However, it does mean that the work tends to be intellectually stimulating (although not always - see below!).  Again, though, I think that increasingly this is no longer the case - I don't think that BP necessarily attracts the best anymore. 

There is potential to move across the business and locations, although getting this realised can be difficult.  More often that not, it is a case of which job is available at the time that you are looking, and there is an increasing emphasis on gaining depth in an area rather than broadening your experience.  This means that increasingly it can be difficult to get out of an area once you have worked there for a while.
cons:
There is poor recognition of good performance.  This is particularly the case for theose on the graduate scheme where you see no promotion and minimal salary increases for three years, no matter how well you perform and how good this performance is relative to your peers.  Beyond this time horizon, many people seem to stagnate into their positions and find it difficult to make headway.  

Many people have been employed by the company for a long long time and have never worked anywhere else.  This can make it quite claustrophobic and inward looking place to work.  It also means that as a newcomer, it can be difficult to make headway.  However, I do think that this is less of a problem than it used to be.

Benefits, although relatively good, are being cut back on.  The best example of this is the scaling back of the compressed working week arrangement by which you  were allowed every other Friday off in return for working longer hours during the preceeding nine days.  There is no health insurance provision in the UK (although you get discounts on private health insurance) or dental insurance (although this is subsidised in some locations - this disparity is somewhat unfair).  Salaries are below the market rate in teh areas that I am familiar with (Finance, Subsurface) and the benefits do not compensate adequately for this.  Holiday allowance is pretty much on a par with other companies in the UK.

The company is slow to move, and often misses out on opportunities because of this.  Proposed activities are analysed to death and are then subjected to round of approval after round of approval.  There have been reorganisations to try and combat this, the effects seem to be slow in coming but I do think that things are improving.  This makes it a frustrating place to work in many ways.

Increasingly, work has involved checking data, producing reports, reconciling sets of information, making presentations, putting numbers into spreadsheets.  This is very very dull, but is part of the redefiniton of roles and reorganisation of the company referred to above.

pros: There are still good people here. Five weeks annual leave helps.
cons: Ever since the big oil spill, it's been all about cutting costs. 3 restructures in the last 18 months have changed the face of the company. They claim to try to do less with less, but truth be told, it's about trying to do the same amount of work with less staff, and the impact is telling.

pros: The company gives you time to settle. Great pay and benefits. It's a good choice if you're looking for something long term. You can move around a lot and try different things if you ask for it.
cons: It's an old company with lots of fear and politics. It's also an oil and gas company so there is a certain amount of denial involved in the business.

pros: Good people, benefits, work life balance, compensation.  It is a good work/office environment that is fairly constructive
cons: You have to play politics to get promoted, projects change/get cut often which kills motivation to perform, management makes all the decisions and doesn't keep the rest of the organization in the loop, lots of water cooler talk prevents things from getting done, lots of red tape

review_title: Mostly good, but a little out of touch
pros: They pay is great, as are most of the people. Doing real engineering work that is varied every day is a joy.
cons: There's a large disconnect between blue and white collar elements of the workforce. Some of that is physical distance between the white collar employees and the manufacturing equipment and personnel, but some of it is cultural.

pros: A professional working environment which is in a state of constant change.  Generally a very relaxed working environment with a strong ethos of flexible working.
cons: Can be very bureaucratic at times with a lot of meetings to agree a decision.  Very heavy HSSE focus across the business - even in offices with a "stair" policy.  The shadow of the Gulf of Mexico tragedy hangs over the company

pros: First years were the best in terms of actual work progression and development. More opportunities to actually do satisfying and challenging work as junior engineer and see the benefits/ results.
cons: Lack of actual concretization of the career progression plans as a whole to enable intellectual fulfilment. At the end leads to complete confusion as to what the person will do the next day that will be able to fulfil the person's intellect, etc....

pros: Decent Perks if you work at a main campus. The pay was better than most of its competitors and better than a comparable job in another industry.
cons: If you are anything but an engineer there is very little growth available in the company. You will be married to the job or business unit you were hired into. Unfortunately the culture became very toxic during the 2015 downturn and layoffs did not consider contributions or performance ratings.

review_title: A great company to work for at the onset of your career in the industry
pros: Great and knowledgeable colleagues, very smart individuals to learn from and impeccable team spirit even in turbulent times.
cons: It is an HR run company and line managers have little or no way of rewarding higher performers without breaking 'HR rules on remuneration'. Rubbish bonus scheme

review_title: Great pay and benefits, but no career opportunities or training for non-engineers.
pros: Pay and benefits are top notch for the position that I am in.   NOTHING gets done quickly at this company and it never seems anything has a "deadline" placed on it.
cons: It is the most bureaucratic place I've ever worked.  Everything has to be decided by committee as no one has the power to make a decision.   No one wants to be responsible for a bad decision, and just keeps passing the buck hoping it will "go away".

pros: Geologists and engineers are valued. Usually relaxed working conditions. Great gyms on campus and next to running trails.
cons:
The company is going through changes and there are waves of layoffs happening. Layoffs will continue with low commodity price through 2015 and 2016. 

Lots of process to slog through. For everything. From transferring files to one another to parking in the garage, to book a meeting room.

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Their family/work life balance is excellent. BP is a company that cares and jumps into action when a crisis arises. There is much opportunity, encouragement and support for career and personal advancement. This is a company that keeps up with and embraces new technology.
cons: I have no negative input nor any criticism on the overall performance of this company on a personal or business level.

review_title: Low pay, low morale, low recognition, growing dissatisfaction among the troops
pros: Come and go as you please; ok office location; they try to do nice things for the employees
cons: few, if any, advancement opportunities, e.g. old timers waiting around to get packaged out; record profits the last several years with little giveback to the employees, e.g. bonuses cut, no merit increases, etc.; just a "weird" place to work

pros: The company really look after it's employees, from health and safety (BP are big on this) to social life. They pay very well and I found the job to be of low stress.
cons: Might be difficult to progress quickly through the company as I believe they still have rules on being in a position for a minimum of 2 years before being promoted. Lower level staff aren't always informed directly on their impact on the company.

review_title: Company with great potential if only we could convert this to great performance results.
pros: Many opportunities to do different things due to the diverse nature of the business.
cons: Leadership, values and morals a big farse. Too much emphasis on the old boys network. HR the biggest problem, top to bottom overhaul essential. HR makes and breaks the rules with impunity.

review_title: Some groups are great to work for, but other groups are quite tough... very dependent on the team leadership.
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits, good people, plenty of opportunity to be challenged technically.  Will miss the relationships with my peers more than some of the leadership
cons: If you aren't in the right circles, you might not get promoted.  It feels like playing politics is more important than delivery of results and building the right relationships.

review_title: Management and tactical strategy at British petroleum as of the start of my career and the developpement of my goals in this company
pros: The strong team building that is due to the underlaying manager that pushes the employees to take iniatives and report actions that are not normal dyring daily activities
cons: There is a lot of cons but so it is the case of every job in any field and in my personal opinion abd without mitigation i can state that the only con that i perceive is the long working hours

review_title: Very interesting and diverse work which requires me to stretch myself in both technical understanding and project skills
pros: Flexible working hours in a very diverse and interesting industry. The role requires me to apply my technical and project management skills to help the PGM deliver the project scope.
cons: Relocation across the world at short notice can be difficult. There is a significant employee age gap between the younger graduates and the older senior staff. Project and operating performance is reliant on the commodity price, meaning the industry is cyclical in investment decisions which affect jobs.

pros: BP offers competitive pay and excellent benefits. They offer good opportunities for learning and advancement. BP believes in giving back to the community and offers a wide range of opportunities for employees to help make a difference.
cons: Change can be slow at BP due to the size of the organization. Work life can be stressful at times. with a lot of rework due to poor decision making.

pros: good benefits, flexible office hours, well location campus, relocation package was good, on and off-campus training were nice
cons: office was too crowded, rest room was too small (200 cubes per floor shared two stands and three seats in one man's restroom), office politics prevailed technical excellence, too much waste in global operation (global meetings, global business travels, etc.), too many self-claimed experts; too many meetings

pros: Great benefits (salary, medical & health options, vacation, education). Good, smart co-workers. Generally engaging work. Some opportunities to move locations. Some flexibility around work hours and tele-commuting.
cons: Relatively frequent organizational changes which create ongoing job insecurity. Employees can be treated like interchangeable pieces. Some policies are more preached that practiced.

review_title: Work hard and long for decent wages and benefits
pros: Large size and name recognition.  Excellent benefits / perks.  Decent salary - if you have leverage to negotiate.  Nice severance package for long term employees.
cons: Expect to work long and hard for those $$$.  Work-family balance is more of a joke the higher you climb.  Expect frequent re-orgs and downsizing.  No loyalty to long-term employees.

pros: Great benefits.  They take very good care of their employees.  Able to achieve good work/life balance.  Challenging environment with promise for future growth.
cons: Limited upward potential and at times even lateral movement within the company.  Very hierarchical and I often felt restricted due to bureaucracy and middle management's personal agendas.  Lots of favoritism.

job_title: Supply Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Very mature business.  Global scale provides global opportunities for employees.  Company has well established training programs.  Aspires to have a Diversity & Inclusion agenda.
cons: Focus of company (especially Refining & Marketing) is on safe, compliant and reliable operations.  In general, that's a good thing.  Unfortunately, that focus has largely eradicated the focus on a profitable and efficient operations.  The commercial agenda has taken a back seat.

review_title: Too many restructures, now run by unskilled Managers not leaders
pros: Salary is fair and good benefits
cons: The culture has dramatically changed in the past 3 years, from many departmental restructures.  What is left is a large number of unqualified Managers with poor people skills, that run and hide from confrontation or questions.

pros: free coffee at work and 50% discount  on eats for staff working more than 6 hours a shift
cons:
- duty managers like to boss a lot,  
 - i didn't like the fact that they paid my monthly salary on the 15th of every month yet i started working on the 1st that meant that i used to get my salary after working 45 days every month

pros: working at bp as a cashier you will meet any people and regular customer which will help you to have great interacting with customer skills. when it's not busy you chill for a bit and you will be on your own because in a small Petrol station there is always one staff
cons: manager and area managers are never happy with your work. always moan about not doing anything, as they do not understand that we work under pressure and it's always busy so never get time to tidying up or do something else.

review_title: Struggles with leadership in L48 business

pros: Very good company,they take care of you and develop your career at all stages whether you are local or expat staff, especially if you joined new project in the middle east.
cons: Low payment for local staff compared to international staff but that is everywhere even in England,  in developing countries, no chance to go international unless you have good recommendation from your line manager

pros: One of the best place to work -- Work-life balance is very good; welfare is one of the best compared to other companies; colleagues are friendly
cons: Have to finish your work fast -- working overtime is sometimes considered as inefficient. Occasionally, politics can get to you.

job_title: Maintenance Engineer in Texas City, TX
pros: Money is good for plant work, medical and benefits are great. Upstream offers a lot more than downstream.
cons: Engineers are not compensated very well. Long hours, called in on weekends. Take work home. Management does not value employees. No formal training, not many opportunities for mechanical engineers. Compensation is not the same for employees in different departments.

review_title: No Advancement, No Benefits, No Raises for 4yrs need new job.
job_title: Gas Station Attendant in Bronx, NY
pros: I like the fact that you are in control of business while your working there is no one over your shoulders but your responsible for everything.
cons: People not coming in on time always late when it's my time to be releaved. Again no insurance or benefits for 40 hrs worker I thought you were to get benefits for full time workers

job_title: Mechanical Engineering Intern in Houston, TX
pros: Treat interns well, fun internship. Travelled offshore, which was fun! Well paid, very good opportunities through the internship, for networking, professional growth, etc.
cons: Recruiting program is not the most organized. Received email saying I did not get internship, followed by one a few days later saying I was selected to be an intern. Very competitive when looking for full time offer after internship.

review_title: BP Alaska PMT and Activity  Planning Functional Lead
job_title: PMT Functional Planning Lead in Anchorage, AK
pros: Good overall review. Good Benefits. In general the Management structure in Alaska worked fairly well. I will work for BP again if given the opportunity
cons: Some large companies take time to adapt new technological advances resulting in inefficiencies and delays.  Implementing changes also takes more time and cannot guarantee to work.

review_title: Good salary & benefits, opportunities to move internationally, promotes from within, bureaucratic.
job_title: Supply Financial Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Salary, benefits and work life balance are all good (at least compared to consulting). Its competitive, but not nearly as competitive as consulting so easy to stand out if that's your background.
cons: The industry is volatile with oil prices and goes through periodic reorganizations. Need to be strategic about the positions you select at the Company to make sure you remain valuable. Yearly average pay bumps are low unless you're a really good performer. This is pretty common for large corporations though.

review_title: nice place for part time work
job_title: Customer Service Associate in Salisbury, England
pros:

- great management - most are promoted from within and are young so treat you like a friend.
- good training if you want to become a manager

- can easily suggest days I do not want to work and they wont book me in (flexible)

- can get quite boring

pros: Great environment with  the brightest managers in the industry.  Lots of challenges. Lots of flexibility to grow jobs around individual talent.  Many international opportunities
cons: Long hours, as an example, the company offers flex Fridays at some locations, but those who aspire to move upward frequently miss those days off

review_title: Good place to start out career to learn skill sets
pros: BP is a stable company with many opportunities for those who are willing to pursue them hard. It is a great place to pick up analytical skill set and looks solid on a resume.
cons: Very hard career advancement as those benefits are given to the Challenger program....especially in trading. Lots of red tape and very hard to advance out of the middle office.

pros: It’s a great multinational experience; I loved working with people from all around the world. It’s also a company who knows how to create long time fidelity, I met lot of employees working there for a long time, and I spent myself more than a decade in BP.
cons: The group has lots of procedures and offer lots of opportunities, but at country level many of them are not properly implemented and enforced.  It’s a lot of room for improvisation and shortcuts. That’s unfortunate.

review_title: business analyst working on one of BP's international business segment's strategy
pros: well-established corporate governance, well supported personal development (good mentor program), encourage diversity and inclusive culture, most time has good work-life balance, non-aggressive corporate culture
cons: inefficiency due to all kinds of internal control and process driven practices. Due to its support to talents' personal development, the senior management changes every 2-5 years, and subsequently a lot of unnecessary organizational changes all the time

review_title: Your succes as an employee is in your line manager's hands
pros: The company looks after its people and tries to do the right thing.
cons: You are completely at the mercy of your line manager, try not to get an insecure and incompetent one.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: BP offered a multicultural and fruitful work environment. Whilst involved in the development of a lignocellulose project in Brazil, all stops were pulled to ensure I had the conditions to access the internal and external knowledge pool for a successful implementation.
cons: Unfortunately, a global strategy review resulted in the lignocellulose technological path being abandoned at the end of 2014. Howerver painful, the company took care in ensuring the way out for all concerned employees was smoother with outplacement packages and some of the benefits being extended for 12 months.

pros: Excellent pay, decent benefits. Lots of overtime, but only on a voluntary basis. Lots of room for advancement, and excellent union protection.
cons: Company does not care if they kill people. BP has killed before and will kill again. They stretch people and equipment to the limit to save money then act surprised when they blow things up.

pros: Great place to work. Benefits are competitive and the employees really want to do what is right for the organization.
cons: Current oil prices make improvement dollars hard to come by.   The organization truly wants to improve its  processes, but cannot provide funding as we are managing revenue due to commodity.

review_title: Think about where you end up.
pros: BP has a  Dynamic environment. It's a large corporation and generally there are many opportunities to move around. Also the interaction and networking opportunities are great.
cons: Highly disorganized. Sometimes I wait for days before a problem is rectified. It's highly inefficient, and it's mind boggling how such a large institution can function with such an inefficient approach.

review_title: A great experience that opened my horizons
job_title: Senior Operations Engineer in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: Professional and supportive company at every level and every location.  Tries hard to do the right thing both environmentally and in business.
cons: large company, so a little hard to get things done quickly.

review_title: Great salary and overall total rewards package!
pros: BP has a fantastic total rewards package, with salary, 401K, portable retirement, annual bonus, and stock.  They are competitive with any of the other oil majors.
cons: Lots of intelligent people work for BP.  They don't always work towards a common goal.  Managing down is not always a strong suit.

pros: Work is easy - you don't need to work really hard. Good for work-life balance. For the level of work you do, pay is good. There are really smart people.
cons: Work is not challenging and motivating. You are not making much progress. There is a big push for values and behaviours but when you actually pursue it you get shot down for being persistent. Totally hypocritical.

pros:
Incredible benefits
Great atmosphere among field personnel
Even when I was new to the group, I felt like my effort mattered.
cons: I was let go when oil prices fell but as the company was finishing up its reorganization. My only complaint was the confusion caused by the reorganization but I believe that the situation as a whole was going well.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: great benefit package.  I was impressed with the 401K, bonus and relocation benefits.  The interview process was swift.
cons: There were overpromises made and unclear job directives when I started. This lack of clarity never resolved itself. I believe the confusion came from management at the facility.  There was evidence that site management was not clear of progress made to upper management offsite.

pros: Ability to work with very smart and talented colleagues. Good compensation and benefits. Very interesting and challenging work, when it's available.
cons: BP's business model is not well suited for low to moderate oil prices.  Leadership remains very financially focused.  The company would benefit greatly from having executives with inherent strength in running a business.

job_title: IT Support in Milton Keynes, England
pros: Great place to work with many good people. Renumeration and benifits good, but pension scheme for new joiners not as good as it used to be. Redundancy package was very generous.
cons: BP don't like doing IT any more. Anything that requires technical knowledge is outsourced to global service providers. All previous technical roles are gone and replaced with vendor managers who know nothing about the systems they are supporting.

job_title: Customer Service Representative- Cashier in Littleton, CO
pros: This was one of my favorate jobs while working retail. Pay was fair. Rewards for performance. They made me feel like much more than a number, and training was excellent.
cons: Some of my coworkers dabbled in drug use. Other than that, it was an ideal employer. Hours were odd at times, but you would expect that at any similar job. Lots of turnover.

pros:
Relaxed, casual work atmosphere
Friendly people, always willing to help
A lot of training available  -- classes, workshops, etc.
cons:
In terms of procurement, very unorganized. Difficult to find data. Can be attributed to the fact that BP is such a large global corporation.
No company mandates, makes it hard to implement procurement policies

review_title: BP is a great organization with great pride to work for.
pros: You get to work in a great team environment that can make you a lot of money and is great when your off for a couple days.
cons: Very dangerous because of the chemicals that are around that are constantly being heated up and put through a variety of equipment.

review_title: Good company, but site has culture challenges

Community involvement

pros: Lots of new things to learn, i was hired as a mature hire and was given lot of responsability quickly, opportunity to get involved in lots of events, very friendly atmosphere

pros: BP is a company that's diverse and opened to upper mobility, career-wise. I found it to be a good place to work.
cons: BP, at the time I worked there, did not have the programs to  promote educational endeavors for all employees. A company this size should have this kind of incentive.

pros: Good work-life balance, generally a positive atmosphere, opportunities to learn and develop and available if proactive. Good working environment. Some good projects to work on.
cons: Career progression in the company is very slow. Managers have a tendency to focus upwards rather than looking after development of their team. No defined mentoring or coaching for junior staff.Path to higher levels of management of technical specialism not clear.

pros: a caring oil company compared to its peers. Its willing to listen to your career aspirations and tries hard to make reasonable requests work. Have friends at the other oil majors who feel like numbers and have little control over career trajectory and location
cons: Often to process bound and unable to make a decsion without months of analysis. People who have the 'right fit' appear to be promoted over more technically competent others. Very disorganized on run on spreadsheets

pros: The benifits are good. There are places within the company and the world to go. We do a great job with dealing with the enviroment
cons: Is so big that things run slow. So many layers of management that some people have a job that is not needed. Bosses come and go too often, they need to stick put for a while. No local techinal support, it is all in Houston.

review_title: Truly a great place to work
pros: Great place to work. Competent management and motivated co-workers. Company really cared about employees well being and there was great opportunity for professional growth and development.  The Carson plant had a lot of great people and strong culture left over from the ARCO days.
cons: BP seemed to go a little overboard on all the feel good sometimes.  Would have liked to see a little more focus on results and performance.  And, of course, the spill in the Gulf was challenging.

review_title: Great experience working with this company, until I was let go.
pros: Good set of values. Great benefits and pay. There are a number of personal and professional development opportunities available. If you can get them, international assignments can be both challenging and rewarding.
cons: Too much politics among those in leadership at times. Constantly changing strategies around organization and operating model (that are sometimes opposing) leaves employees confused and de-motivated.

pros: the benefits are great, they still offer a pension.  The core values are a nice environment to work in and the salary tends to be at the top of the scale.
cons: Favoritism is far too common, spend way too much time on things that don't apply to building a business and stock price is still under pressure

job_title: Subject Matter Expert in Warrenville, IL
pros: The experience is good and introduces you to the corporate world. Most areas allow room to grow if you put in the effort and seek out opportunities.
cons: Poor leadership, fail to inspire people to work harder. Poor talent recognition. Low salaries in the GBS. Very clique oriented.

pros: BP as a large corporation does provide benefits that are above average.  It has many programs in place to help with Diversity.
cons: No concern for the individual employees.  Recent centralization of many job functions, has removed the local decision making from those that understood the systems best.

review_title: Good Company, Lots of Mgmt Turnover
pros: Very understanding of work-life balance.  Very good bonus structure.  Lots of diversity in age/race.  Very supportive of advancing education.
cons: High turnover rate for managers.  You will have a new boss every 2-3 years.  Feedback is not offered, rather folks will talk about you behind  your back.  Hard for women to advance.

pros: Plenty of training with room to grow and advance.  I found everyone to be very professional and was very impressed with the place overall.
cons: Great Place, but I found the safety requirements a little to tedious to maintain.  The rules for parking in the garage are strenuous and if you break them you will have to park in the open lot.

pros: Access to continuing education, good total compensation, organization built on strong core values, and job responsibilities that clearly correlate to the mission of the business.
cons: Leadership tone def to morale of mid and low level employees. lack of succession planning,  organizational changes occur far too often to add value.

review_title: Great Company & People, but Frequent Uncertainty
pros: Great company with amazing benefits.  Love my coworkers and the great work/life balance.   Culture promotes safety like no other!
cons: Constant transformations & reorgs.  Management can seem distant from the actual problems on the front line.  Company has complex processes, which results in things moving very slowly..

review_title: Progressive, Performance Driven, Innovative and Green?  Not so much any more.
pros: BP previously provided excellent opportunities for international mobility.  The downside was that there was no clear strategy for how to manage expats.
cons: The lack of leadership at BP is evident over the past few years.  An organization that once prided itself on being "progressive" has allowed itself to become stagnant as Senior Management shows more concern for staying in their post and less driving a strategy that once made BP the pride of the energy sector.

review_title: BP is a wide open, flat organization.
pros: The compensation is in line with the industry, but the learning is where the opportunities really stand out.  What I take away from it all on a daily basis has really helped my job growth in the time I've been with the company and hope to continue at my current pace.
cons: The hours can be long, but the work is rewarding in what Ive been able to take away as lessons learned.

review_title: Good Opportunity but politics and people pleasing can be exhausting.

cons: Politics are very important there and everyone in leadership seems to need to give the "ok" before a project can move forward. BP seems paralyzed by past mistakes and their desire for extensive analysis.

review_title: Senior Associate in SPI group (Sustainable Performance Improvement)
job_title: Senior Consultant, Sustainable Performance Improvement in London, England

Compensation was not adequate for the hours worked or length of time away from home.  I did not find the promotion opportunities or long term opportunities attractive either.

pros: Good work life balance and fair compensation structure. Emphasis on internal development and training.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Warrenville, IL

review_title: BP is great company to work for

review_title: World class training for exciting career

cons: Sometimes the process of large corporations can bog down efficiency, but there is a reason the process is in place, especially post-Macondo. The "safety moments" can be a excessive.

pros: Lots of job security working with a lot of hardworking and intelligent people. Plenty of resources as your disposal, as long as oil prices remain high. cons: To many layers of managements and slow at implementing new ideas.  New idea generation takes a long time until it can be reviewed and possibly acted upon.

pros: Big company, loads of development opportunities, exciting industry, experienced colleagues, great opportunities to move roles within the company, flexible working.
cons: Very process driven, therefore sometimes reduces creativity. It takes time to get things done. Sometimes you might be stuck at the same level and find yourself in a position that it is easier to move externally.

job_title: Staff Scientist in San Diego, CA
pros: They have generous benefits and a strong emphasis on safety. You can move up, if they like you. You can spend money if needed.
cons: A bit of an over-emphasis on safety in some cases. A rigid bureaucracy is in place in many areas which makes things slow. Travel is restricted. Things are very tight at the moment, company is contracting in many areas.

pros: Great company culture, offers good number of flex days, compensation package is competitive, opportunity for a variety of work and exposure to different projects.
cons: Recent economic downturn has resulted in world wide reductions in staff but local managers have done their best to not have that result in increased work load for remaining staff, instead focusing on high value work.

pros: Pleasant and talented people, flexible hours, reasonable compensation, Awesome facilities at larger sites, always treated professionally by managers. time management.
